message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals in the synovial fluid suggest calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudogout. Elevation of serum uric acid concentration is seen in gout, not pseudogout. Expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is seen in conditions such as ankylosing spondylitis and reactive arthritis. Thickening of the synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, not pseudogout. Calcification of the meniscal cartilage is a finding commonly seen in pseudogout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of positively birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid under polarized light suggests calcium pyrophosphate crystals, and the characteristics of the effusion and erythema support this diagnosis of pseudogout. Calcification of the meniscal cartilage is a common finding associated with pseudogout. Thickening of the synovia is associated with rheumatoid arthritis and elevated serum uric acid concentration is associated with gout. Expression of HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis. None of these are likely to be found in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positively birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals indicated that the patient likely has gout. The other options are not associated with gout. Calcification of the meniscal cartilage may occur in osteoarthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positively birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals in the synovial fluid under polarized light indicate calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudogout. It typically affects the larger joints, such as the knee, and can result in calcification of the meniscal cartilage. Thickening of the synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints suggests rheumatoid arthritis, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation. Elevation of serum uric acid concentration is not typical for CPPD, but is seen in gout. Expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is associated with spondyloarthropathies, which typically present with axial skeleton involvement and are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of rhomboid crystals under polarized light suggests calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, also known as pseudogout. This condition often affects the knee joint and can cause calcification of the meniscal cartilage. Thickening of the synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is a characteristic finding in rheumatoid arthritis. Elevation of serum uric acid concentration is seen in gout. Expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is associated with an increased risk for developing spondyloarthropathies such as ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The synovial fluid analysis suggests a septic arthritis caused by crystals, with the positively birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals indicating calcium pyrophosphate crystals. This is consistent with the diagnosis of pseudogout, which can cause calcification of the meniscal cartilage. Thickening of the synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis, while elevated serum uric acid concentration is suggestive of gout. Expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals and a leukocyte count with neutrophil predominance suggests a diagnosis of gout. Option B is the only one that is associated with gout - calcification of the meniscal cartilage. Thickening of the synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, elevation of serum uric acid concentration is also seen in gout but cannot be assumed solely based on the synovial fluid analysis, and expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The finding of positively birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid analysis suggests calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition disease (CPPD). This disease commonly affects the knee joint and can lead to calcification of the meniscal cartilage. Thickening of synovia is a feature of rheumatoid arthritis, and elevation of serum uric acid concentration is a feature of gout. Expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is associated with an increased risk of ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals seen in the synovial fluid analysis suggest calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (pseudogout). Option (B) is the only option that is associated with cartilage calcification. Thickening of synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, elevation of serum uric acid concentration is associated with gout, and expression of HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and synovial fluid analysis suggest crystal-induced arthritis, specifically calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). The positively birefringent rods and rhomboid crystals seen under polarized light confirm the CPPD diagnosis. Thickening of synovia at the metacarpophalangeal joints is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, elevated serum uric acid concentration is seen in gout, and expression of human leukocyte antigen-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis. None of these are associated with CPPD. Calcification of the meniscal cartilage can be seen in CPPD.
